utterances: I'm particularly happy in this new position, I'll continue to work closely with my former colleagues in Congress whose feedback, collaboration and friendship I highly value.
Portman said the president's economic policies have led to a growing U.S.
economy and he said tax cuts enacted in the first term should be made permanent.

His appointment, which still needs Senate approval, is being praised by Republicans, but Democrats used the occasion to point out the record deficits accrued since Mr. Bush took office and to predict Portman won't be turning that around.
After introducing Portman and the new trade rep who replaces him, Susan Schwab, the president said he'd take a couple of questions.
The focus quickly turned to the possibility of more changes among senior staff.
Mr. Bush was asked if Bolten will be seeking resignations.
The president, while not denying that more change is coming, dismissed such talk as speculation over a game of musical chairs.
But I also understand what happens in Washington, you know, little flicker of gossip starts moving hard and people jump all over it.
Now, the thing the American people got to know is we'll structure this White House so that it continues to function to deal with major problems.
When pressed, the president's patience seemed strained.
Unidentified Reporter: (unintelligible)
You don't understand why.
Because we've got people's reputations at stake.
And on Friday, I stood up and said I don't appreciate the speculation about Don Rumsfeld.
He's doing a fine job.
I strongly support him.
It was the president who brought up Rumsfeld's name, seeming to look for an opportunity to put to rest talk that Rumsfeld should go.
I have strong confidence in Don Rumsfeld.
I hear the voices and I read the front page and I know the speculation.
But I'm the decider and I decide what is best and what's best is for Don Rumsfeld to remain as the secretary of defense.
I want to thank you all very much.
With that, the president brought a quick end to the brief question and answer session, if not to the speculation.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, the White House.
Hospitals across the country are feeling the effects of methamphetamine, not only in emergency rooms, but in delivery rooms.
Not much is known about the long-term effects of prenatal exposure to meth.
Research, like the young victims, is in its infancy.
But we do know that the estimated thousands of meth-addicted babies born each year in the US require a lot of care.
Patricia Murphy of member station KUOW in Seattle profiles one woman who has made caring for these newborns her life's work.
PATRICIA MURPHY reporting:
Dressed in a denim pinafore and a neatly starched blouse, Barbara Drenin(ph) looks like the perfect mother.
She oozes empathy, the kind that makes you want to show her your scraped knee just so that you can get a hug and a cookie.

For 40 years, Drenin's maternal instincts have led her to foster children in need, but her mission since the early '80s has called her to care for some of the most vulnerable: babies born addicted to drugs.
This was a labor of love.
It wasn't anything I would have ever dreamt that I would ever do.
But she saw a need, she says.
These infants were being cared for in the hospital and Drenin thought she could offer a more nurturing environment in her home.
She began fostering these special-needs babies.
The work was overwhelming.
And then the state stepped in and said she needed a license to do it.
(Soundbite of babies crying)
With that, the Pediatric Interim Care Center in Kent, Washington, was born.
Unidentified Woman: She's not happy.
(Soundbite of baby crying)
From The studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand joined by my faraway colleague, Alex Chadwick.
Hi, Alex.
Yes.
Violent clashes have erupted in the capital and actually throughout the country between protesters that support Guaido and forces that are loyal to Maduro.
At least, for the moment being, more than three dozen people have been wounded, some of them with bullets.
And as you said, in Caracas, an armored vehicle ran into a crowd of Guaido supporters, wounding one of the protesters.
There's a mix of hope, but there's also a lot of confusion and chaos.
It seems that people don't know that much what to do or where to go.
What they know is that they want to stand there and remain on the streets to support interim President Juan Guaido.
So some people remain firmly planted on the streets.
But does it seem like many people are afraid to even be out today?
That's weird.
When I ask people - I met a woman this morning.
She said she's not afraid.
Here she is.
(Speaking Spanish).
In that clip, she said that if Guaido is not afraid, if Leopoldo Lopez is not afraid, how would she be afraid?
She said that, no, she will stand next to them firmly.
And Mariana, do you have any idea how much of the current military is siding with Guaido's side?
I think that's a question that everybody is asking themselves right now.
It is not clear how many militaries are on the side of Guaido at this moment being.
When I was in this public square where Guaido gave a speech earlier, I just thought, like, maybe 20 of them, not more than that.
It is unclear if the military uprising is only in Caracas or inside of the country.
Having that kind of information in Venezuela, taking into account the level of censorship and the level of repression as well is very, very difficult.
Mariana Zuniga is a freelance journalist based in Caracas.
Thank you very much.
You're welcome
Yola Carter spent years building a reputation as a pop singer and songwriter-for-hire in the U.K.
And then she chose to start over as a solo act.
Carter has just released her full-length debut using only her first name, Yola.
Jewly Hight reports on what she's singing now.
Yola Carter caught the music bug as a very small child growing up in a tiny seaside town in southwest England.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOLLY PARTON SONG, ""JOLENE"")
Browsing through her mother's record collection, she latched onto a 1974 Dolly Parton album.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""JOLENE"")
(Singing) Jolene, Jolene, Jolene, Jolene.
I'm begging of you, please don't take my man.
It never crossed Carter's mind that that wasn't what an aspiring singer who happened to be black and British was supposed to be listening to in the late 1980s.
I didn't know that it was going to be such a problem until I started trying to actually do it.
And then people were like, now, this is weird, OK?
We always thought that you'd sing R&B.
I'm like, why?
My voice doesn't sound like that at all.
When Carter first started getting asked to perform in her teens, she had to conceal it from her mother, a nurse, who insisted that her children pursue similarly stable careers.
Carter had to sneak out to club gigs and studio sessions.
She went on to arrange vocals and write lyrics and melodies over others' music.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""HOPES AND FEARS"")
(Singing) If you could shed a little light on, no matter how far away.
Baby, baby, shed a little light on, no matter how far away.
Working under her given name, Yolanda Quartey, she eventually contributed to pop hits and dance smashes, too.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""BLIND FAITH"")
(Singing) The music that we play will ease your mind.
A lot of that kind of work was being this gun-for-hire, and you just have to do whatever the brief said.
It's all singing work, broad-ranging and not really me exploring who I was.
Carter was forced to stop everything for a year and a half when she lost her voice in 2007.
She studied anatomy and came up with her own program for vocal care.
Once she could sing again, she split her time between the renowned electronic group Massive Attack and Phantom Limb, a band she'd formed with several rock musicians.
With Phantom Limb, she inched closer to the music she wanted to make.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""THE PINES"")
(Singing) It's clear - yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah - to a minor or a massive degree, yeah.
Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.
Got to start thinking free.
But Carter still felt she was compromising a little too much.
She became friends with a folk guitarist named Kit Hawes, who helped her gain independence by learning his instrument.
